warrant.translation[0].definitions[0].de: a legal document that is signed by a judge, allowing the police to take a particular action
warrant.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: The magistrate issued a warrant for his arrest.
warrant.translation[0].definitions[1].de: an official document giving someone the right to do something, for example buy shares in a company
warrant.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: The company issued warrants for 300,000 shares.
warrant.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: This tiny crowd does not warrant such a large police presence.
Another area that warrants attention is that of funding for universities.
warrant.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to promise that something is true
warrant.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: The Author hereby warrants that the Publisher is the owner of the copyright.
warrant.translation[2].definitions[0].de: an official document giving someone, usually an existing shareholder, the right to buy shares in a company. Warrants are similar to RIGHTS ISSUEs, except that holders usually have longer to use them
warrant.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: The warrant entitles the company to buy 300,000 common shares for $18.50 each.
Each £5,000 bond carries one stock warrant exercisable five years from now.
warrant.translation[2].definitions[1].de: an official document giving someone the legal authority to do something
warrant.translation[2].definitions[1].ex: The attorney’s officefiled a warrant seeking the forfeiture of the illegal assets.
According to thearrest warrant, one of his victims was a widow with nine children.
warrant.translation[3].definitions[0].de: to promise that something is true or to guarantee that something will happen
warrant.translation[3].definitions[0].ex: Investors expect the auditors to warrant information contained in the accountants’ report.
If the purchaser wishes specific matters to be warranted, these should be set out in detail in the contract.
